Summary My research goal is to development clinically useful monoclonal antibodies for therapy and diagnosis. 
 
• Extensive and diverse experiences in molecular biology and antibody engineering. 
• Experience in hybridoma technologies, antibody library construction, phage/mammalian cell display, B cell cloning, cell line development, Luminex, cell-based high-throughput screening for hybridomas, cancer target selection using data mining, animal experiences (lung fibrosis and xenegraft tumor model) 
 
• Cover all aspects of therapeutic antibodies discovery from target selection to animal experiments including 
- Target selection using data mining  
- Production/purification of antigen in mammalian cells 
- Target screening using phage/mammalian cell display 
- Recombinant antibody production/purification 
- Functional study of the antibody in vitro and in vivo 
- Therapeutic effect of antibodies on animal model

•	Recombinant antibody/proteins production 
•	Cell line development and cell-based bioassays

Summary I’m biologist and biochemist with experience in RNAi therapeutics, cardiovascular research, enzyme biochemistry, and natural products research. I am a goal-focused, highly motivated professional with a unique background that includes a Ph.D. in Biochemistry, as well as post-doctoral work in both Biochemistry and Cardiovascular Medicine. 
 
I am trained in biochemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology, and have extensive experience conducting and leading research studies, grant writing, and training and mentoring students and less experienced researchers. Presently, I am part of the National System of Researchers (SNI), a governmental agency of Mexico. I conduct studies using RNA therapeutics and genetic manipulation. 
 
I am a seasoned researcher and collaborative professional who thrives on the challenges of creatively and resourcefully solving problems. I recently co-filed a patent application for a method for treatment of cardiomyopathy using RNA interference. Additionally, I am a hands-on leader with a solid understanding of laboratory techniques and safety guidelines, with the ability to safely and effectively manage multiple projects simultaneously.  
 
I thrive on new challenges, and am eager to expand my experience while applying my communication, problem-solving, scientific, and leadership expertise. Please feel free to contact me at ktzaleta@gmail.com with any thoughts, comments, or questions about my work or qualifications, as I am always interested in making new professional acquaintances. Basic Life Science Research Associate Stanford University School of Medicine September 2006  –  November 2011  (5 years 3 months) •	Generated three microRNA conditional knockout mouse strains that form the basis of all on-going mouse projects in the lab. 
•	Discovered a novel role for microRNAs in autoimmune diseases with potential therapeutic applications in treating Multiple Sclerosis. 
•	Manage all mouse usage and coordinate and supervise mouse colony maintenance. 
•	Supervise and train postdocs and graduate students on mouse husbandry. 
•	Designed and carried out novel techniques to investigate microRNA functions. 
•	Part of a collaborative team to study microRNA biogenesis and analyze primary, precursor and mature microRNA syntheses and turnovers. •	Generated two knockout strains that became the basis of a graduate thesis project that led to the discovery of a novel function in forebrain patterning. 
•	Collaborated in two projects to investigate signal transduction and transcriptional regulation during neural development. 
•	Supervised various graduate rotational projects and an undergraduate honor’s thesis. Some of these activities include:

-Characterized cell based potency assay for ICHQ2R-type validation 
-Developing analytical methods such as ELISA to define release specifications of WNT3A and L-WNT3A 
-Developing a novel method to express and purify the hydrophobic WNT3A protein in serum free conditions

-Optimizing purification and designing scale-up for large scale protein purifications,  
-Leading collaborative efforts between industry experts in Biochemistry and Protein Purification, as well as tracking and reporting on these collaborative partnerships.

Summary Passionate for discovery with hope of a deeper molecular understanding of life to the benefit everyone. My greatest dream is to discover something that will have a positive impact on the lives of many people, either those living now or in the future. 
 
My main strengths as a scientist besides the standard "analytical and goal oriented": 
 
1. I am very curios. Childish at times. I am itching for a my next discovery. 
 
2. I am relentless in my pursuits but cognizant of the inherent frailty of any concept. I have strong opinions but ready to change perspective at the drop of a hat in light of experiments=data driven.  
 
3. I have learned to be very patient.  
 
Complemented and modulated by traits or principles:  
 
4. I am a direct communicator. 
 
5. My strongest driving force is the common good. 
 
6. It is second nature to me to provide ideas and create solutions for the group in a selfless manner. In my ideal work place this is appreciated and rewarded.  
 
My research profile: 
Molecular biologist, biochemist and structural biologist with specialization in X-ray crystallography. Expert in structural mechanisms of nucleotides, nucleotide analogs, inhibitor and co-factor binding. In particular protein-ligand and protein-nucleic acid interactions either in enzyme catalysis or allosteric regulation of enzyme activity. Current focus is on RNA structural changes underlying cancer causing silent mutations. Summary Passionate for discovery with hope of a deeper molecular understanding of life to the benefit everyone.
